issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: The problem described is an issue which will never be fixed.
resolution.name: Won't Fix

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
After launching console log in as aact1/user1 -> log out
try logging in as acct2/usr2, the result is "Please change password, as it expired " message, when in fact password is still valid.

This is cause by xrsf token being incorrect, and user can log in after refreshing the browser.
fields.summary: User is given a "Password expired" mesage when xsrf token is invalid.

comments.body: I have seen this message also when I switched from source to packages and opened UI in IE 10 browser that was freshly launched.
This issue is in my opinion customer affecting as they will do the same after update.

The simplest fix is to simply not require the xsrf token on login any longer.
Other "fixes" are more graceful failures. For example, if a user logs in with the wrong password, they get an error, but then logging in with the right password fails for this xsrf reason. In that case, I'd refresh the page after the login failure, which would be pretty transparent to the user.
In the case of the proxy re-start, we'd need to give a better error, then refresh the browser instead of the current "change your password" dialog.

Hi [~dkavanagh], thanks for pointing out the other use case (incorrect password). What are the other places where the xrsf token changes the console behavior? I just did the negative test for incorrect password. My reasoning - as a user - in this use case would be that I must probably change password for security reasons, and it would not occur to me to refresh console after changing password...  I think this should be fixed.

I have a simple fix for the incorrect password use case.
the big change here was around using the xsrf token with login. During normal usage, the session would not outlive the xsrf token, so a user would be bounced back to login anyway.
fix pushed to EUCA-8390 branch for the incorrect password case. I wasn't able to cause the other case where the proxy is restarted and login fails unless the login page is refreshed.
Oddly, I still cannot reproduce the proxy-restart failure mode. Here's a PR for the incorrect password case: https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucalyptus-console/pull/247

Use case:

I left the session open in my FF 25 browser. Put computer to sleep. In the morning pulled in new packages, restarted console. The session was in the browser, non-expired. On click I saw the loading icon, waited for a while, still no "Session expired message". I logged out , and then logged in again. That's when I saw the "Password expired" message.

Just tested the case when user enters invalid password with code from the the fix branch: https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucalyptus-console/tree/EUCA-8390

I can see the refresh after the "wrong user name/password combination" message is confirmed and there is no  "Password expired" message.

I just ran into this. I was verifying some bugs, logged out and tried to log back in and I got the "Password expired" message. I was using Chrome and I never saw a  "Session expired message" or any other error message before I got the  "Password expired" message.

Tested with console built from source with code from EUCA-8390 branch. I can not see the bug when I stop/start proxy. However I ran into the bug initially when I stopped the console that was built from packages and launched the console from cloned EUCA-8390 branch.
Hi [~mmunn1] That is odd, since xsrf cookie should be valid for 12 hours. [~dkavanagh], does it vary browser to browser?

I dug a lot deeper on the xsrf token and how tornado uses it. We're doing our own session mgmt, so the default check for a logged in user failed and we never had the long-lived xsrf cookie that tornado used by design for a login screen (30 days). Now, I've fixed that and we do generate a long lived xsrf cookie until the user logs in, and then the cookie expires when the session does.

https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucalyptus-console/pull/247

Hi [~dkavanagh], Just tested the console with code from EUCA-8390 branch. I stopped services, cloned console, launched with launcher.sh 
Verified log in with correct/incorrect pwd works as expected both to Eucalyptus and AWS. Could someone please merge the fix?
The pull request no long exists
When checked the pull request 247, seeing that it has been merged.
Just pulled in the latest packages for 3.4.2. The password change on expiration is still broken.

for debugging, here are some helpful commands;
# euare-usermod --delegate test2 -u sjones --pwd-expires
'2013-03-05T17:15:00Z'
# euare-usergetattributes --show-extra --delegate test2 -u sjones
arn:aws:iam::test2:user/sjones
RWBGUBE8M3FVKZBKSO9NZ
true
CONFIRMED
Tue Mar 05 09:15:00 PST 2013
I just tested on the setup Alice provided and it functioned properly.
I tested again, and this time it worked. I will do more testing, to see if the issue can be reproduced under certain conditions.
Odd to assign fix version as 4.0 since the codebase is entirely different. Perhaps we should just clear the fix version if it won't be 3.4.2
[~tjcramer]. please see my last comment.
This was re-architected in 4.0.  Reopen if a fix is desired in a later 3.4.x branch.
